meanings.definition: Make (guilt or an offense) seem less serious or more forgivable.
meanings.sent1: She tried to extenuate her mistake by explaining the circumstances.
meanings.sent2: The lawyer attempted to extenuate the crime by highlighting the defendant's difficult upbringing.
meanings.sent3: His attempt to extenuate his lateness with a wild story only made his boss more suspicious.
meanings.sent4: The apology letter was a feeble attempt to extenuate the hurtful words spoken.
meanings.sent5: Her tears did little to extenuate the impact of her actions on her friend.

meanings.definition: Serving to make a fault, offense, etc., appear less serious.
meanings.sent1: The extenuating circumstances led to a lighter punishment for the young offender.
meanings.sent2: The judge considered the extenuating factors before sentencing the defendant.
meanings.sent3: His extenuating excuse for being late was that he lost track of time playing video games.
meanings.sent4: The extenuating evidence presented in court changed the course of the trial.
meanings.sent5: The extenuating circumstances surrounding the accident made it difficult to assign blame.
